questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true?
  1. Morphine is used in pulmonary edema
  2. Pethidine can be used in biliary colic
  3. Indomethacin is used for headache
  4. Aspirin can be used in peptic ulcer disease
  5. Pethidine is used in post-anesthetic shivering
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, 3 & 5 are true.

Option 1: Morphine is used in pulmonary edema due to its vasodilatory and anxiolytic actions.

Option 2: Morphine should be avoided as it causes constriction of the sphincter of Oddi causing an increase in fluid pressure in the common bile duct and gall bladder. Pethidine causes lesser spasm of the sphincter of Oddi and can be used in biliary colic.

Option 3: Indomethacin is an NSAID used in headache.

Option 4: The use of aspirin can worsen peptic ulcer disease.

Option 5: Single dose of pethidine (meperidine) can be effective in the treatment of postanesthetic shivering.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week for the past 1 year. A detailed investigation was done to rule out the organic cause. What should be the treatment plan for this child?

choices.text: Bladder training, with reward for delaying micturition during daytime
Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of nocturnal enuresis. Bell and pad based classical conditioning is the most effective treatment.

Nocturnal enuresis refers to the occurrence of involuntary urination at night after 5 years of age. It may be a normal phenomenon in children up to 5 years of age.

Treatment for nocturnal enuresis may include:

Behavioural therapy:

  • Classic conditioning with the bell (or buzzer) and pad (alarm) apparatus is the most effective treatment for enuresis.
  • Dryness is achieved in 50% of the cases.
  • Bladder training with encouragement or reward for delaying micturition for increasing times during waking hours is useful but considered inferior to bell and pad.

Pharmacotherapy:

  • Medications should be considered if behavioural therapy has failed, and if enuresis is causing impairment in social, family, and school function.
  • Desmopressin (an antidiuretic) and Reboxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor) are commonly used drugs. Reboxetine is considered as a safer alternative to imipramine.

Psychotherapy:

  • It is indicated in cases with chronic enuresis, to deal with any coexisting psy­chiatric problems and emotional and family difficulties.

questions.text: The normality of 2M HCl is ___  as 1M H2SO4.
questions.solution:
The normality of 2M HCl is the same as 1M H2SO4.

Normality of a solution can be calculated from its molarity by multiplying it by its valence. Valence is the number of protons a salt releases in aqueous solution.

Here Valence of HCl is 1 while H2SO4 is 2. 

Hence Normality of HCl = 2M x 1 = 2 N

similarly Normality of H2SO4 = 1M x 2 = 2N

Normality is defined as the number of gram equivalents dissolved per liter of solution. Where gram equivalents are the number of moles of a solute multiplied by its valence

Molarity is defined as the number of moles of a solute dissolved per liter of solution.

questions.text: What is the gold standard diagnostic test for airborne contact dermatitis?
questions.solution:
The gold standard test for airborne contact dermatitis is a patch test.

Patch testing is done to document sensitivity to a specific antigen. Patch test antigens comprising suspected allergens are applied to the patient’s back and covered for 48 hours. After the patch is removed, the area is examined for delayed type of hypersensitivity.

The image below shows a patch test.

questions.text:
Which of the following is seen in freshwater drowning?

1. Haemodilution
2. Hypokalemia
3. Hyponatremia
4. Arrhythmia
questions.solution:
In cases of freshwater drowning, hyperkalemia is seen due to hemolysis of swollen RBCs and not hypokalemia.

Freshwater is hypotonic to plasma and is rapidly absorbed from the alveoli and into the RBCs. The RBCs finally swell up and lyse resulting in the release of intracellular potassium causing hyperkalemia. Increased intravascular blood volume combined with hyperkalemia causes arrhythmia. 

Seawater is hypertonic to plasma and causing a shift of fluid from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary edema. There is a net decrease in blood volume causing a fall in blood pressure.

questions.text:
Match the following Escherichia coli with its pathogenesis/virulence:

1. ETEC

 a. Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanyl cyclase

2. EIEC

 b. Invades intestinal mucosal cells

3. EHEC

 c. Produces a toxin against vascular endothelium cells

4. EPEC

 d. Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli
questions.solution:
Option C: 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d is correctly matched.

Escherichia coli strains Pathogenesis

ETEC- Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli

 Produces a heat stable toxin and causes activation of guanyl cyclase

EIEC- Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli

Invades intestinal mucosal cells

EHEC- Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli

 Produces a toxin against vascular endothelium cells

EPEC- Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli

Adheres to mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli

 

The various strains of Escherichia coli are:

  1. Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism causing traveler’s diarrhea. It produces the following enterotoxins:
    1. LT (heat-labile toxin)- acts by ↑cAMP
    2. ST (heat-stable toxin)- two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II)
      1. ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by ↑cGMP in the intestine. 
      2. ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known.
  2. Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) invade interstitial epithelial cells in the intestine and cause a condition resembling shigellosis. This ability is determined by a plasmid, detection of which can also be a diagnostic test.
  3. Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin or Shiga-like-toxin, which targets vascular endothelium. It causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome.
  4. Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile diarrhea in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of small intestine using EAF (EPEC adherence factor) and LEE (Locus of enterocyte membrane) and causes effacement of microvilli. This leads to attachment and effacement lesions of intestinal cells.
  5. Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) produces the stacked brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells. EAEC has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by AAF (aggregative adherence fimbriae). EAEC produces EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) which is considered to be a major virulence factor.

questions.text: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painful lesions as shown in the image. What is the most likely microscopic finding of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Clusters of vesicles are seen on an erythematous base in the image, suggesting a diagnosis of genital herpes. Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cells are present on microscopy.

The Tzanck smear is a rapid, sensitive, and inexpensive diagnostic method for herpes simplex infections. Smears are prepared from the lesions, from the base of vesicles and stained with a 1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds. Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground glass chromatin (Tzanck cells) are seen.

Mucocutaneous herpetic lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers which heal without scarring.  Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy may be seen. The most common site of cutaneous lesions is the face - on the cheeks, chin, around the mouth, or on the forehead - and is caused by herpes simplex virus-1. Genital infections are more commonly caused by herpes simplex virus-2.

questions.text: The position of the patient in the image shown below is known as:
questions.solution:
The above image shows a reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient's head is elevated 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. It is named so, as the position is reverse of the Trendelenburg position, where the head end is lower and the feet are at a higher level.

The Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as the small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and sideboards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.

In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the patient is placed in a reverse Trendelenburg position slightly rotated to the left. This exposes the fundus of the gallbladder which is retracted towards the diaphragm.

Other options: 

Option A: Lloyd Davies's position is a 30-degree Trendelenburg position with the hips flexed at 15 degrees. It is used for rectal and anal canal surgeries like low anterior resection and abdominoperineal resection. It can cause compartment syndrome of the calves.

Option B: Jackknife position is a modified prone position where the patient's hips are supported on a pillow and the table is flexed at a 90-degree angle with the head and feet at a lower level. It is not used anymore due to the chest compression causing impaired ventilation leading to positional asphyxia. It was used for hemorrhoids and fissure surgery. 

The image below shows commonly used patient positions in the operating room:

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigation is used for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of repeated transfusion, low hemoglobin level, and target cells in the smear are suggestive of thalassemia. Globin gene sequencing is used for its definitive diagnosis. 

High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is used as a screening test for thalassemia (option A). 

Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into α-thalassemia and β-thalassemia.

β-thalassemia is caused by point mutations of the β-thalassemia gene on chromosome 11, which diminish the synthesis of β-globin chains. Splicing mutations are the most common cause of (β+) thalassemia. 

There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in β-thalassemia. Children with severe thalassemia present with distinctive facial features such as maxilla hyperplasia, a flat nasal bridge, and frontal bossing. Other manifestations include pathologic bone fractures, significant hepatosplenomegaly, and cachexia. 

Blood smears show marked anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, and microcytic hypochromic anemia. Target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells also are common. A radiographic image of the skull shows the classic 'crew cut' appearance.

Hb Electrophoresis and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) are used as screening tests for thalassemia. DNA diagnosis to detect β-thalassemia mutations is used for definitive diagnosis. The Mentzer index is the ratio of MCV to RBC count. It is used to differentiate between iron-deficiency anemia and β-thalassemia trait. The Mentzer index is <13 in thalassemia minor syndrome.

Transfusions are administered every 3-4 weeks to maintain a pretransfusion hemoglobin level of 9.5-10.5 g/dL. Transfusion-induced hemosiderosis is a significant complication in transfusion-dependent thalassemia. Iron deposition occurs in the liver, endocrine organs, and heart, resulting in complications including hypothyroidism, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, growth hormone deficiency, hypoparathyroidism, diabetes mellitus, heart failure, and arrhythmias. 

The image below shows thalassemic facies and crew cut appearance on X-ray:

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A patient presented with massive abdominal swelling. Paracentesis fluid was sent for lab analysis and results show serum protein to be 3g/dL and ascitic fluid protein to be 1g/dL. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario with serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) >1.1g/dL [calculated as serum albumin level - ascitic fluid albumin level, which in this case is 3-1=2g/dL] and ascitic fluid protein <2.5 g/dL is late Budd Chiari syndrome.

Serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) can be used to differentiate between ascites due to portal hypertension and non-portal hypertensive ascites. It represents the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids and correlates with the hepatic venous pressure gradient.

It is given by the formula: SAAG = Serum albumin level - Ascitic fluid albumin level

Interpretation of SAAG:

  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

In cases with high-SAAG (≥1.1), ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology:

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites as in early Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein as in late Budd-Chiari syndrome

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: What is the approximate age of a person in whom the medial end of the clavicle is fused and also the  sternum is completely fused

Approximate age for the given person with fused medial end of clavicle and completely fused sternum is most likely >25 years.

questions.text: As filtrate flows through PCT,  the concentration of all of the following decreases except:
questions.solution:
As the filtrate flows through the proximal convoluted tubule, the concentration of the chloride increases.

  • The concentration of chloride in the early part of the pCT is ≈105 mEq/L.
  • As the sodium is reabsorbed, it preferentially carries glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate.
  • This leaves behind the solute, that has a higher concentration of the chloride, which as it reaches the second half of the PCT is ≈140 mEq/L.

Related Pearl: Summary of Transport Across Proximal and Distal Portions of the Nephron

Variable amounts of filtered PO43- and other electrolytes reabsorbed; subject to control

Almost all filtered K+ reabsorbed; not subject to control

questions.text: The level of visceral pleura goes up to which of the following levels during deep inspiration?
questions.solution:
The visceral pleura is adherent to the lung. During deep inspiration, the lung moves into the costodiaphragmatic recess and may reach up to the level between middle and lower one-third of the right surface of the liver, which is marked as 'C' in the given image.

Relations of the right surface of the liver:

  • Upper one-third: It is related to the diaphragm, the parietal pleura, visceral pleura and the lung.
  • Middle one-third: It is related to the diaphragm, cost-diaphragmatic recess.
  • Lower one-third: It is in direct relation to the chest wall.

During quiet respiration, the lungs do not fill the costodiaphragmatic recess, so it reaches up to a level between upper and middle one-third (Level B, as shown in the image). However, during deep inspiration, they move into the costodiaphragmatic recess and reaches up to a level between middle and lower one-third (Level C, as shown in the image).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is suffering from increasing difficulty in bending forward with increasing stiffness of the spine and reduced chest movements. A CT was performed and shown below, the likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 40-year-old man with increasing stiffness in the spine, along with CT spine showing ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament and ankylosis involving the thoracolumbar vertebral bodies points to a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis (AS).

AS is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is more common in young males and has a strong association with HLA-B27.

Features of lower back pain in AS:

  • Age at onset < 40 years
  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness > 30 minutes
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Pain persists with rest and is also present at night.
  • Alternating gluteal pain
  • Persistence for more than 3 months 

Examination findings in AS:

  • Loss of lumbar lordosis
  • Increased thoracic kyphosis
  • Diminished spinal movements
  • Decreased chest expansion ( <7 cm)
  • Tenderness over sacroiliac joints

Important X-ray features of ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Sacro-iliac joints:
    • Cardinal sign/earliest sign is the erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints
    • Later- periarticular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint.
  • Vertebral changes: 
    • Early spondylitis is characterized by small erosions at the corners of vertebral bodies with reactive sclerosis: Romanus lesions of the spine (Shiny corner sign)
    • Squaring of vertebral bodies or flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the spine due to inflammatory resorption of the bone.
    • Later signs are ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs producing syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance is due to bridging at several vertebral levels
    • Linear ossification along the central spine, representing interspinous ligament ossification can give a Dagger sign appearance on frontal radiographs.

CT imaging in AS helps to visualize bone erosions, osteoporosis/osteosclerosis, and new bone formation in the form of syndesmophytes, ligamentous ossification, and ankylosis.

The X-ray below shows the bamboo spine appearance in AS:

Related Pearl: Ankylosing Spondylitis VS Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis

           DISH         AS
Etiology Idiopathic Autoimmune
Age group Older patients (middle-aged) Younger patients
HLA No evidence of association with HLA-B27 Strong association with HLA-B27
Lab investigations Non-specific and inconclusive High ESR and CRP
Syndesmophytes Nonmarginal Marginal
Radiograph "Flowing candle wax"  "Bamboo spine"

Associated disease Obesity, diabetes mellitus, hypervitaminosis A Autoimmune conditions like iritis, uveitis, ulcerative colitis

questions.text: The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is:
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events for PCR among the given options is denaturation, annealing, and extension.

The process of PCR is as follows:

The DNA sample is first heat-denatured at >90°C (90-96 degrees Celsius for 3 minutes) to separate the two strands of the template DNA containing the target sequence; the primers (which attach to the 3' end of the flanking sequence) are added in excess, are allowed to anneal to the DNA (typically at 50-75°C) in order to generate the required template-primer hybridization complex. Under suitable conditions and presence of deoxynucleotides, elongation of the DNA stand occurs. 

The number of copies produced in the presence of an unlimited supply of deoxynucleotides and enzymes is given by - 2 to the power n (where n is the number of PCR cycles)

  • 20 cycles provide an amplification of 220 = 106  or 1 million copies
  • 30 cycles provides an amplification of 230 =109 or 1 billion copies

Below is an image showing the various ingredients for carrying out PCR.

questions.text: On your morning walk in the park, you notice an unconscious man lying on the ground. Which of the following options would be the next best step?

choices.text: Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help; Defibrillate if no pulse.
Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

questions.solution:
The next best step is to Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate If no pulse.

Steps in basic life support:

First step – Assess safety of the surroundings.

Second step - Assess for responsiveness

Third step – Proceed if the patient is unresponsive. Shout for help.

If the patient is unresponsive, assess for breathing and carotid pulse simultaneously for no more than 10 seconds.

In the given scenario, it is already mentioned that you are in a park (scene safety has been assessed), and that the person is unconscious (responsiveness has been assessed). So, the immediate next step is to call for help, and start CPR.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below. 

Related Pearl: Basic Life Support (BLS) Algorithm

questions.text: A midwife is examining a pregnant woman in labour when she noticed that the cord is prolapsed. What should be the next immediate step of management?

choices.text: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina
Inform the doctor and shift to OT
Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.solution:
In this scenario the midwife should put the pregnant women in a Trendelenburg position or in an exaggerated and elevated Sims’ position with a pillow or wedge under the hip or thigh.

Caesarean section is the recommended treatment of choice for cord prolapse. Prior to performing the procedure, several measures can be taken to alleviate cord compression. These measures involve:

  • Manually elevating the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the entire hand through the vagina
  • Positioning the patient in steep Trendelenburg, exaggerated Sim's position, or knee-chest position
  • Filling the bladder with 500–700 cc or more of saline (known as the Vagos method)

After the diagnosis of cord prolapse is made, it is crucial not to attempt cord replacement. Such attempts are not only ineffective but also result in the inevitable rupture of the membranes, leading to cord prolapse.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with long hands and feet, and a protruding lower jaw. Which of the following genes is most likely implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Mutations of the pituitary-specific gene PIT-1 can lead to the development of a somatroph adenoma which produces elevated levels of GH Growth hormone (and IGF-1) which can lead to acromegaly as given in the clinical scenario above.

Somatotrophs, mammosomatotrophs, and lactotrophs are derived from stem cells that express the pituitary transcription factor, PIT-1.

If the increased levels of GH are present after closure of the epiphyses, acromegaly develops. In this condition, growth is most conspicuously seen in

  • Skin and soft tissues, viscera (thyroid, heart, liver, and adrenals).
  • The bones of the face, hands, and feet are thickened and enlarged.
  • Bone density may increase (hyperostosis) in both the spine and the hips.
  • Enlargement and protusion of the jaw is seen (prognathism), and broadening of the lower face.
  • The feet and hands are enlarged, and the fingers become thickened and sausage-like.

GH excess can also be associated with a variety of other manifestatiions, like gonadal dysfunction, diabetes mellitus, generalized muscle weakness, hypertension, arthritis, congestive heart failure, and an increased risk of gastrointestinal cancers.

Other options:

Steroidogenic factor -1 (SF-1) and GATA-2 are factors that are required for gonadotroph differentiation.

questions.text: Calculate the respiratory quotient (RQ) in a patient with 50kg body weight, if the CO2 exhaled is 200ml/min and O2 consumed is 250 ml/min.
questions.solution:
The respiratory quotient is 0.8.

The respiratory quotient is the ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen utilization.

In the given question, the CO2 production is 200mL/min, while the O2 consumption is 250mL/min.

Therefore,

Respiratory quotient = 200/250 = 0.8

 

The respiratory quotient (RQ) is used for determining the metabolic utilization of various foods.

  • When carbohydrates are metabolized with one molecule of oxygen, one carbon dioxide molecule is released. Therefore, the RQ of carbohydrates = 1.
  • When fats are oxidized, for every 100 molecules of oxygen consumed, 70 molecules of CO2 are released. Therefore, the RQ of fats is 0.70.
  • Similarly, the respiratory quotient for proteins is 0.80.

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiate delirium from dementia in Alzheimer's disease?

choices.text: Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

questions.solution:
Delirium is characterized by acute onset of symptoms and is often accompanied by diminished or loss of consciousness and cognition. This feature is useful to clinically differentiate between delirium and dementia. 

Dementia is a group of diseases marked by chronic, progressive cognitive impairment with clear consciousness.

Associated physical findings
  • Acute medical illness 
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Abnormal EEG 
  • Carphologia or floccillation (picking movements at cover-sheets and clothes) 
  • No medical illness
  • Little autonomic dysfunction
  • Normal EEG 

Psychological findings
  • Impaired consciousness
  • Illusion, delusion 
  • Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night) 
  • Normal consciousness
  • Depressed mood 
  • Personality changes in early stages in Pick’s disease 
  • Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night) 

Course
  • Develops quickly
  • Fluctuating course with lucid intervals (waxing and waning) 
  • Insidious-onset
  • Progressive downhill course
 

Etiology
  • CNS disease (E.g: Huntington or Parkinson disease)
  • CNS trauma
  • CNS infection (E.g: Meningitis)
  • Systemic disease (E.g., hepatic, cardiovascular)
  • Substance abuse/withdrawal
  • HIV infection
  • Prescription drug overdose (E.g: atropine) 
  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Vascular disease (15-30% of all dementias)
  • CNS disease (E.g., Huntingtons or Parkinsons disease)
  • CNS infection (HIV, Prion diseases)
  • Lewy body dementia
  • Pick's disease (Frontotemporal dementia) 
 

Treatment:

 

Treat the underlying medical cause

Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) and NMDA antagonist (memantine)

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio?
questions.solution:
The disruption of zonula occludens is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio cholerae.

Zonula occludens toxin (Zot) is an enterotoxin elaborated by Vibrio cholerae that increases intestinal permeability by interacting with a mammalian cell receptor with subsequent activation of intracellular signaling leading to the disassembly of the intercellular tight junctions.

Mechanism of action of cholera toxin:

  • The cholera toxin molecule consists of 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The A (active) subunit, on being transported into the enterocyte, dissociates into A1 and A2. A2 fragment only links biologically active A1 to the B subunit.
  • A1 causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to outpouring into the small intestinal lumen, of large quantities of water and electrolytes. This leads to watery diarrhea which is isotonic with plasma but contains much more potassium and bicarbonate.
  • The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride.
  • All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the massive water and electrolyte depletion thus caused.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text:
True regarding POAG.
  1. Abnormality of the trabecular meshwork is seen on gonioscopy
  2. Family members are likely to develop steroid responsiveness.
  3. Dilatation of pupil is associated with exacerbation of IOP
  4. First degree relatives are at 1% increased risk of POAG
  5. Visual field defect can exist with normal C:D ratio
questions.solution:
Statements B and E only are correct.

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), is also known as chronic simple glaucoma of adult-onset.

 

POAG is characterized by:

  • Increased intraocular pressure:
    • IOP >21mmHg on more than one occasion, and/or
    • Circadian variation in IOP of >8 mmHg, or
    • Asymmetry in IOP > 5 mmHg between both eyes
  • Optic nerve head changes suggestive of glaucomatous damage. These may include one or more of the following changes:
    • Cup-disc (C:D) ratio > 0.5 (Normal 0.3)
    • Asymmetry in C:D ratio >0.2 between both eyes.
    • Narrowing, notching or pallor of the neuroretinal rim.
    • Disc haemorrhages.
  • Visual field changes.
  • Defects in the retinal nerve fibre layer.

 

A diagnosis of POAG can be made, if at least 2 of the first 3 criteria, mentioned above are met. In patients diagnosed with POAG, with normal cup-disc ratio and raised IOP, the visual field defects may occur due to damage to the retinal nerve fibre layer.

 

Risk factors:

  • The higher the IOP, the greater the likelihood of glaucoma
  • Myopia is associated with an increased incidence of POAG
  • There is 10% increased risk of POAG in siblings and 4% increased risk in children of patients with POAG (not 1%)
  • Patients with POAG and their offspring and siblings are more likely steroid responders i.e they respond to 6 weeks topical steroid therapy with a significant rise of IOP.

 

Other statements:

  • Statement A: Inability to visualize trabecular meshwork on gonioscopy indicates primary angle-closure glaucoma. 
  • Statement C: Primary angle-closure glaucoma is associated with exacerbation of IOP with pupillary dilatation (not in POAG).
  • Statement D: As mentioned above, there is a 10% increased risk of POAG in siblings and 4% increased risk in children of patients with POAG.

questions.text:
Which of the following enzymes are involved in gluconeogenesis?
  1. Pyruvate carboxylase
  2. Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase
  3. Hexokinase
  4. Pyruvate kinase
  5. Glucose 6 phosphatase
questions.solution:
Pyruvate carboxylase and glucose-6-phosphatase are enzymes used in gluconeogenesis. These enzymes catalyze irreversible steps of gluconeogenesis.

Glycolysis and gluconeogenesis are 2 metabolic pathways in opposite directions (glucose being the substrate and product respectively). The reversible enzymes are common in both pathways. But a few reactions are not reversible in glycolysis. So a different pathway is used or a different enzyme is used by the body to make the reactions feasible.

At the start of gluconeogenesis, pyruvate carboxylase (Option 1) catalyzes the synthesis of oxaloacetate from pyruvate following which phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase converts it to phosphoenolpyruvate (not phosphoenol pyruvate kinase as in Option 2). Alternatively, at the end of glycolysis, the reverse of this reaction occurs in a single step catalyzed by pyruvate kinase (Option 4).

At the end of gluconeogenesis, glucose 6 phosphatase (Option 5) converts glucose-1-phosphate to free glucose and is an irreversible process. Alternatively, glycolysis starts with the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate by hexokinase (Option 3).

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

Pyruvate → Oxaloacetate

mitochondria

Biotin, ATP

Activated by acetyl-CoA
Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase Oxaloacetate → PhosphoenolPyruvate (cytosol) GTP
Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate → fructose-6-phosphate (cytosol)

Citrate(+ve)

Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate (-ve)
Glucose-6-phosphatase Glucose-6-phosphate → glucose Endoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: The brace shown in the given image is _____.
questions.solution:
The brace shown in the image is the Milwaukee brace.

The Milwaukee brace is an active corrective spinal orthosis primarily used in the ambulatory treatment of structural scoliosis. Designed as a cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO), the main objective of the Milwaukee brace is to delay or eliminate the need for surgery. However, in recent years, the use of the Milwaukee brace has declined due to the availability and convenience of modern braces. Nonetheless, it is still employed for scoliosis cases characterized by high thoracic and cervical spine curves.

Option A: Boston brace is a type of thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside. It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower. The below image shows a Boston brace.

Option C: Taylor brace is designed to control the upper and lower regions of the spinal column and support your spine whilst standing, sitting, and walking after spinal surgery.

Option D: ASHE brace (Anterior spinal hyperextension brace) is used in dorso lumbar spinal injury.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding mechanisms of depolarisation, repolarisation, and hyperpolarisation in a skeletal muscle action potential?
  1. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels
  2. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through ligand-gated channels
  3. Repolarisation due to efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channel
  4. Repolarisation due to efflux of K+ through ligand-gated channel
  5. Hyperpolarisation due to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3, and 5 are correct.

Action potential in skeletal muscle:

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes end-plate potential, which when reaches to a threshold value, causes action potential in the muscle fibre.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fibre is caused by the activation of the voltage-gated sodium channels, which causes the influx of sodium.
  • During repolarization, the sodium channels are closed, and voltage-gated potassium channels open, which causes efflux of potassium.
  • The voltage-gated potassium channels close slowly. As a result, the potassium efflux continues, leading to hyperpolarization of the membrane.

The steps in an action potential in muscle fibre and the neuron, are similar except for the quantitative differences, such as:

  • RMP is -80 tp -90 mV in skeletal muscle fibres, while it is about -70mV in neurons.
  • The duration of the action potential in skeletal muscle is 1 to 5 msec, which is about 5 times longer than in the largest myelinated nerve fibre.
  • The velocity of conduction is about 3-5m/s, which is about 1/13th of the velocity of the nerve fibre.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. He had a fever for the past two days and is a known case of severe COPD. His ECG is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pulmonary disease and the ECG showing different p wave morphologies are suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia.

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) occurs due to impulses arising from multiple abnormal foci in the atria. This leads to supraventricular tachycardia with p waves and QRS complexes of different morphologies. It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness. 

Therapy for MAT is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities. Calcium-channel blockers and radiofrequency ablation of the AV node are the other treatment modalities.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals, hence it can be atrial fibrillation or multifocal atrial tachycardia. The next step is to look at the p waves. Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image). Whereas, in atrial fibrillation, there would be no distinct p waves seen.

questions.text: A patient presents with urethral discharge. A gram stain smear is made from the discharge sample and the following microscopic image is seen. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above image shows gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes in a stained smear from the urethral discharge sample, which is seen in infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

According to CDC recommendations 2021, the first line of treatment in uncomplicated gonococcal infections is a single dose of ceftriaxone 500 mg IM.

Note: BASHH (British Association for Sexual Health and HIV) in the United Kingdom also recommends higher doses of ceftriaxone of about 500 mg along with azithromycin because it would result in fewer failures.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the ER with headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 hours. A CT image is shown below. Physical examination shows positive Kernig’s and Brudzinski’s signs. Vitals: Temp - 101 F, BP - 120/88 mmHg, PR - 110 beats/min, pupils reactive. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and the treatment of choice for this condition is surgical clipping. 

CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space, which is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.

SAH can present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign, and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.

Treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine (60 mg PO every 4 h) improves outcome, by preventing ischemic injury.

Option A: Vancomycin + ceftriaxone is the recommended therapy for bacterial meningitis. Meningitis does not show hyper-attenuated subarachnoid space.

Option B: IV Tenecteplase is used for ischemic stroke without bleeding complications.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old female patient presents with a 4*3cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast, which is not fixed to the skin or the chest wall. A lymph node of 2cm is palpated in the right axilla. No mass is palpated in the opposite breast. Which of the following investigations would you perform on this patient?
  1. Bilateral mammography
  2. PET Scan
  3. Biopsy of the breast mass
  4. USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of breast malignancy with locoregional spread with unlikely distant metastasis.  For further evaluation of this lesion, bilateral mammography, a biopsy of the breast mass and a USG-guided biopsy of the suspicious lymph node need to be performed in order to determine staging and decide on further management. 

Statement 2: PET Scan is usually performed in advanced cases of breast cancer. It is not routinely used in the assessment of locoregional disease.

Statement 1: Diagnostic mammography is used to evaluate women with abnormal findings such as a breast mass or nipple discharge. Mammography is more accurate than clinical examination for the detection of early breast cancers. Mammographic features suggestive of breast cancer include a solid mass with or without stellate features, microcalcifications, irregular soft tissue shadow, spiculations and duct distortion.

Statement 3: Pathological diagnosis of carcinoma is made by a core needle biopsy (tru-cut biopsy) or fine-needle aspiration before any type of treatment is started. 

Statement 4: The presence or absence of axillary lymph node involvement in breast cancer is one of the most important prognostic factors for determining staging and treatment. Ultrasound-guided lymph node biopsy should be done in patients with suspicious or clinically palpable lymph nodes. 

Ultrasound features suggestive of breast cancer include a hypoechoic, irregular mass with indistinct, angulated or spiculated margins, acoustic shadowing, ductal extension and a branched pattern of mass.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features of benign and malignant breast lump on USG

Benign lump Malignant lump
Hyper echoic Hypo echoic
Oval, well circumscribed lump Lump will be taller than wider
Thin echogenic pseudocapsule Ill defined echogenic halo
Peripheral vascularity Central vascularity
  • Most sensitive and most common finding of malignancy on USG – Lump will be taller than wider.
  • Most specific finding of malignancy on USG – Central vascularity

questions.text: A child presents to OPD with tense bullae over the torso. Biopsy of the lesion showed a subepidermal level of blistering and neutrophil infiltration. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with tense blisters showing subepidermal separation and neutrophilic infiltration at the basement membrane points towards a diagnosis of IgA pemphigoid or linear IgA disease or chronic bullous disease of childhood. The drug of choice is dapsone. It is bacteriostatic against M. leprae.

It also has an anti-inflammatory action by decreasing the action of neutrophil enzymes. Hence, it is useful in the treatment of IgA pemphigoid, linear IgA disease and chronic bullous disease of childhood.

questions.text: A bus conductor was diagnosed with varicose veins. On examination, skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis were noted. According to the CEAP classification system, He would be classified as
questions.solution:
According to CEAP classification, varicose veins with skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis come under the clinical class of C4.

The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as,

  • C4a- pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b- lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c- corona phlebectatica

Recent 2020 update on the CEAP system:

  • C2r for recurrent varicose veins
  • C4c for Corona phlebectatica
  • C6r for recurrent active venous ulcer.

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a dry cough. A chest X-ray reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest x-ray shows a pattern of lymph node enlargement seen in sarcoidosis.

The characteristic pattern of lymph node enlargement in this condition is called the Garland triad or 1-2-3 sign, or pawnbroker's sign. The lymph nodes involved are:

  1. Right paratracheal nodes
  2. Right hilar nodes
  3. Left hilar nodes

Image showing a pattern of lymph node enlargement (1-2-3 sign):

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows large cylindrical worms with tapering ends, and thus represents Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworm).

Ascaris lumbricoides is the most common of human helminths and is distributed worldwide. It is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine. The adult worms are large cylindrical worms, with tapering ends. The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior. It appears white outside the body. 

Its natural host is humans. There is no intermediate host. Adult worms live in the small intestine - jejunum and ileum. Humans acquire infectionby consuming food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces containing eggs. The eggs contain the infective rhabditiform larva.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct regarding Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome?

1. Arborizing pattern of connective tissue
2. Mutation in the STK11 gene
3. Multiple hamartomatous polyps
4. Autosomal recessive
5. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
questions.solution:
The correct statements regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are 1, 2, and 3.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant, hereditary disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. The pigmentation is particularly evident on the face, buccal mucosa, hands, feet, and perianal and genital regions. This rare syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years.

Germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the gene STK11 are present in half the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Histologic examination shows a characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

A complication of Peutz-Jeghers polyps is intussusception, which is occasionally fatal. Peutz-Jegher syndrome is associated with a markedly increased risk of colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

Note:- Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen in FAP, not Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

questions.text:
A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Which among the following statements is true regarding her condition?
  1. Visible peristalsis from left to right is seen.
  2. The vomitus is generally bilious.
  3. Hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis can be associated.
  4. Cervix sign and antral nipple sign are seen in contrast studies.
  5. The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.
questions.solution:
Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2-8 weeks of age.

When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality i.e hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, the loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone via the RAAS pathway. The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions. Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia. Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of compensating that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine.

The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs of CHPS seen on ultrasonography:

  • Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called nipple sign.
  • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign.

The given ultrasound image shows thickened pylorus, with cervix sign and nipple sign.

Treatment:

  • The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected preoperatively.
  • The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old medical student with dengue developed epistaxis which resolved spontaneously. He has been afebrile for 24 hrs but his platelet count is 18,000. What should be the management?

1. Give 4 units of platelets
2. Give plenty of oral fluids
3. Give IV fluids
4. Keep under observation
5. Discharge the patient
questions.solution:
Options 2, 3, and 4 are correct.

The main pathology in dengue is plasma leakage resulting in intravascular volume depletion and thereby shock. So, supportive management with continuous infusion of crystalloid IV fluids remains the primary modality of treatment in these patients. Oral rehydration is recommended. And often patients respond well to supportive management. 

Prophylactic platelet transfusion is limited to patients with severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm3).

FFP and cryoglobulins are not the preferred treatment modality in dengue.

Warning signs of dengue include: 

  • Abdominal pain or tenderness
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Clinical fluid accumulation (ascites, pleural effusion)
  • Mucosal bleeding
  • Lethargy or restlessness
  • Hepatomegaly >2 cm
  • Increase in hematocrit concurrent with a rapid decrease in platelet count

Inpatient management is advised for all patients with dengue with warning signs.

questions.text: Identify the cells marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
A peripheral blood smear shows RBCs, WBCs (granulocytes and agranulocytes), and platelets.

Granulocytes:

  • Neutrophil - 3 to 5 lobed nucleus with small, bluish granules in the cytoplasm
  • Eosinophil - Binucleate/spectacle shaped nuclei with brick-red granules in the cytoplasm. (1)
  • Basophil- Large bluish granules in the cytoplasm which obscure the nucleus. (3)

Agranulocytes:

  • Lymphocytes- size just larger than an RBC. No granules, no nucleoli present. (2)
  • Monocytes - largest cells with a kidney-shaped nucleus. (4)

questions.text:
Arrange the following events in the sequence in which they occur, after 'p wave' in ECG.
  1. a wave in JVP
  2. First heart sound
  3. Rapid filling of ventricles
  4. T wave in ECG
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events that occur after the p-wave is 1-2-4-3

The sequence of the events in this question can be better understood with the following diagram:

  • The p wave in the ECG represents atrial depolarization, which causes contraction of the atria, represented by the 'a' wave in the JVP.
  • Atrial contraction is followed by the closure of the mitral valve, which causes the first-heart sound.
  • This is followed by the isovolumetric contraction of the ventricle, which causes c wave in JVP, due to bulging of the tricuspid valve. This is followed by the rapid ejection phase of the ventricle.
  • The T wave of ECG occurs during ventricular repolarization, which is followed by the opening of the mitral valve, followed by rapid filling phase of the ventricle.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant on the second postoperative day following a cholecystectomy. Evaluation reveals a collection in the subhepatic space. A bile leak was suspected. Which of the following is the best investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the best investigation in a patient suspected of post-cholecystectomy biliary leaks.

Patients with post-cholecystectomy biliary leak usually present with fever, jaundice and abdominal pain.  USG is used for an initial evaluation in such cases and can show a collection in the sub-hepatic space. 

The most common bile leak following cholecystectomy is from the cystic duct. This can be treated by placing a biliary endoprosthesis (stent) in the common bile duct across the origin of the cystic duct.

MRCP shows fluid collections arising from bile leaks but cannot differentiate these from other causes of fluid collections.

ERCP is the best investigation as it has the advantage of being both diagnostic and therapeutic.  ERCP is useful post-cholecystectomy as there is a high likelihood of a retained stone and stone extraction and/or temporary stenting may be required. 

HIDA scan is the most sensitive investigation for biliary leakage.

CT scan can show focal fluid collections, ascites, biliary obstruction, hepatic atrophy, signs of secondary biliary cirrhosis and any vascular injury.

questions.text:
Match the following poisons with their probable mechanism of action
A. Zinc chloride 1.Abortifacient
B. Chloral hydrate 2. Irritant
C. Quinine 3. Corrosive
D. Potassium carbonate 4. Stupefying
questions.solution:
For the above-given options, the correct match is given as 

Poison Mechanism
A.Zinc Chloride 2. Irritant
B.Chloral hydrate 4. Stupefying
C. Quinine 1. Abortifacient
D.Potassium
carbonate		 3. Corrosive

The rationale for the classification:

Zinc chloride also known as butter of zinc is highly irritant to the eyes on topical application. It can cause erosive esophagitis on ingestion. It has a fatal dose of 350mg. It could've also been classified as a corrosive, but since potassium carbonate is an alkali with stronger corrosive action, it is better classified as an irritant for this question.

Chloral hydrate is a CNS depressant. It is also known as knockout drops because of its rapid action and is used in robbery or rape to quickly render the victim helpless.

Quinine is a cardiotoxic drug with the additional action of being an abortifacient. Its overdose may lead to an echolic action (contract the pregnant uterus)

Potassium carbonate is a caustic alkali with a predominantly corrosive action due to its high pH.

questions.text: What is the most common drawback of the given device?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a metered-dose inhaler (MDI). The most common side effect of this device is drug deposition in the oropharynx. 

Most material inhaled using this device will be swallowed and absorbed, entering systemic circulation after undergoing the first-pass effect in the liver. Some drug will also be absorbed into the systemic circulation from the lungs.

The use of a large-volume spacer will reduce the amount of drug deposited in the oropharynx, thereby reducing the amount swallowed and absorbed from the GI tract, thus limiting the systemic effects of the drug.

The given image shows the use of spacer with MDI:

 

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of the drug inhaled into the lower airways.

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to small children, as young as 3 years of age, who are not able to use a pMDI (pressurized MDI), as seen in the image below:

 

Pressurized metered-dose inhalers: Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and typically deliver 50–200 doses of the drug.

Dry powder inhalers: Drugs may also be delivered as a dry powder using devices that scatter a fine powder dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. Children less than 7 years of age find it difficult to use a DPI. DPIs have been developed to deliver peptides and proteins, such as insulin, systemically but have proved to be problematic because of the consistency of dosing.

The given image shows various types of dry powder inhalers:

 

Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizers are available. Jet nebulizers are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen), whereas ultrasonic nebulizers use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulized drug may be inspired during tidal breathing, and it is possible to deliver much higher doses of the drug as compared to pMDI. Nebulizers are therefore useful in treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD, for delivering drugs when airway obstruction is extreme (e.g., in severe COPD), for delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices, and for giving drugs such as antibiotics when relatively high doses must be delivered.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of the right breast over the past 15 days. On examination, there was local rise of temperature, and the swelling was mobile over the chest wall. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the rapid onset of the disease and the examination findings are suggestive of inflammatory carcinoma of the breast.

Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. It mimics acute mastitis. The hallmark of inflammatory breast carcinoma is the diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatics within the breast and the overlying skin, often without a discrete underlying tumor mass (peau d' orange appearance). The patient presents with rapidly progressive swelling of the breast, warmth, erythema and edema. A breast lump may or may not be present. 

A diagnosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma should be suspected when a patient with rapidly progressive swelling with inflammatory skin changes does not respond to antibiotics. The imaging features with ultrasound and a mammograph is non-specific due to the underlying erythema and edema. A biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis. 

Treatment includes combined-modality treatment:

  • Neoadjuvant chemo­therapy
  • Mastectomy
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hormonal therapy- for ER-positive tumors
  • Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors

Option B: Giant fibroadenomas occasionally occur during puberty. These are benign solid encapsulated slow-growing tumors over 5 cm in diameter. It presents as a painless lump in the breast. They are managed by excision via a submammary incision.

Option C: Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes. It presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition. Benign lesions can be treated with enucleation or wide local excision. Massive tumours, recurrent tumours and malignant lesions are treated with a mastectomy.

Option D: Galactocele are the most common benign breast lesions in lactating women. It is a cystic enlargement of the mammary gland containing milk. They are mostly detected during lactation or in the third trimester of pregnancy but rarely, may also present after stopping breastfeeding. Clinically, the mass is usually firm and non-tender and presents as a solid tumour-like lesion on physical examination. The patient usually notes the lesion during lactation or some period after lactation. Needle aspiration, followed by excision should it recur, is the standard method of treating galactocele.

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of angina/MI. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation?
questions.solution:
The patient may have been given sumatriptan, a 5-HT1b/1d receptor agonist which causes vasoconstriction and used in migraine. Thus, sumatriptan will worsen angina by causing coronary vasoconstriction.

Angina will be worsened if the O2 demand of the heart is increased or there is reduced blood flow to the already ischemic areas.

questions.text: According to Strasberg’s classification of bile duct injuries, injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak is:
questions.solution:
Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct associated with bile leak is classified as Strasberg’s type C injury.

Biliary injury may occur post-laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The most common site of bile leak following cholecystectomy is the cystic duct.

MRCP is the gold standard for complete morphological evaluation of the biliary tree. MRCP with magnetic resonance angiography is more useful in cases of associated vascular injury. A HIDA scan can confirm the presence of a bile leak or biliary obstruction. 

The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is widely used to anatomically define bile duct injuries.

Classification

  • Type A: Bile leak from cystic duct stump or a minor biliary radical in the gallbladder fossa
  • Type B: Occluded right posterior sectoral duct.
  • Type C: Bile leak from the divided right posterior sectoral duct.
  • Type D: Bile leak from the main bile duct without major tissue loss.
  • Type E: Injury to the main hepatic duct; classified according to the level of injury
    • E1: Transected main bile duct with a stricture more than 2cm from the hilus.
    • E2: Transected main bile duct with a stricture less than 2cm from the hilus
    • E3: Stricture of the hilus with right and left ducts in communication.
    • E4: Stricture of the hilus with separation of right and left hepatic ducts.
    • E5: Stricture of the right aberrant sectoral and main bile ducts.  

 

Management of bile duct injuries is shown below:

questions.text: Iritis is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Iritis is seen in all the above conditions except rheumatoid arthritis.

Iritis or iridocyclitis is also known as anterior uveitis. 

Anterior uveitis is seen in:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis
  • Psoriasis
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Leprosy

Posterior uveitis is seen in:

  • Vogt-Koyanagi Harada syndrome
  • Diseases like toxoplasmosis, cysticercosis, coccidioidomycosis, toxocariasis, histoplasmosis
  • Infections- Candida, Pneumocystis carinii, Cryptococcus, Aspergillus, and Cytomegalovirus
  • Cat-scratch disease, Whipple’s disease, and brucellosis

Both anterior and posterior uveitis is seen in:

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Behcet's disease
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Herpes infections, Syphilis, Lyme disease, TB, onchocerciasis

Intermediate uveitis/pars planitis is seen in multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OPD with painful genital ulcers. Which of the following can cause a painful ulcer on the glans penis?
questions.solution:
Painful genital ulcers are caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, and are known as chancroid.

The regional lymph nodes are enlarged and painful. Microscopic appearance seen in H. ducreyi is called the school of fish appearance or railroad appearance. Chocolate agar with isovitaleX is a suitable culture medium for Haemophilus ducreyi.

The given image shows the microscopic appearance of H. ducreyi.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the posterior surface of the femur, and the structure marked is gluteal tuberosity, to which the gluteus maximus muscle is attached. It causes extension and lateral rotation at the hip joint.

The femur can be divided into:

  • The proximal femur - Consists of the head, neck, greater and lesser trochanters. The intertrochanteric line is present on the anterior surface at the junction of the neck and shaft of the femur while the intertrochanteric crest is present on the posterior surface.
  • The shaft of the femur - Consists of linea aspera (bony crest present on the posterior surface), gluteal tuberosity, and pectineal line
  • The distal femur - Consists of the medial condyle, lateral condyle, intercondylar fossa, and patellar surface

The image below shows attachments of various muscles over the posterior surface of the right femur.

Gluteus maximus muscle:

Origin:

  • Posterior aspect of the dorsal ilium, posterior to the posterior gluteal line
  • Posterior superior iliac spine
  • Posterior aspect of sacrum and coccyx
  • Sacrotuberous ligament.

Insertion - It is inserted mainly in fascia lata at the iliotibial band and also into the gluteal tuberosity on the posterior femoral surface.

Action:

  • Major extensor of the hip joint
  • Lateral rotation of the hip joint
  • Active in powerful abduction of the thigh

Arterial Supply - Inferior and superior gluteal arteries and the first perforating branch of the profunda femoris artery.

Nerve Supply- Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1 and S2).

questions.text: Which of the following disease has the highest mortality once clinically manifested?
questions.solution:
Rabies has the highest mortality once clinically presented. 

Rabies is a vaccine-preventable, zoonotic, viral disease of the central nervous system. Rabies virus is a bullet-shaped rhabdovirus containing ssRNA. It spreads to humans by bites or contact with the saliva of rabid animals (bats, dogs, cats). Once clinical symptoms appear, rabies is virtually 100% fatal. The disease can be divided into 3 phases:

  1. Prodromal phase: It lasts 2-10 days. Patients present with malaise, headache, photophobia, vomiting, and fever.  They may also have parasthesias, pain or pruritus near the site of exposure. 
  2. Acute neurologic phase: It lasts 2-7 days. In the more common encephalitic rabies, Hydrophobia (fear of water) or aerophobia (fear of breeze) can be seen. Swallowing liquids precipitates painful spasms of the throat muscles. Patients may also have nervousness, hallucinations, excessive lacrimation, salivation, perspiration and pupillary dilation. Convulsive seizures may occur
  3. Coma and death (due to cardiorespiratory arrest)

In about 20% of patients, paralytic rabies is seen. Flaccid muscle weakness is seen, which progresses to quadriparesis and facial palsy.  

Note: In rabid animals, the virus depicts two modes of spread:

  • Centripetal spread: The virus enters the peripheral neurons. It moves via retrograde fast axonal transport towards the spinal cord or brainstem a.k.a the central nervous system (CNS) at a speed of up to 250 mm/day. Once within the CNS, it spreads quickly to other regions in the CNS through fast axonal transport. It infects neurons primarily, but may rarely infect astrocytes.
  • Centrifugal spread: After CNS infection is established, it spreads along the sensory and autonomic nerves to salivary glands, adrenal glands, skin 

Rabies virus replicates in acinar cells of the salivary glands and is secreted in the saliva of rabid animals that serve as vectors.

questions.text: If codiene is coming to the market in combination with dextromethorphan as an anti-tussive, this combination _______

choices.text: Should not be used due to risk of addiction
Can be used as both have different mechanism of action
Should not be used as it is  irrational
Can be used to treat cough effectively

questions.solution:
It is an irrational drug combination and should not be given.

Codeine is an opioid analgesic having specific antitussive action while dextromethorphan is a centrally active NMDA receptor antagonist that may be effective as an antitussive. Both are centrally acting antitussives, and do not provide any added advantage when combined. Hence it is an irrational drug combination.

Rational fixed-dose combination drugs for the treatment of cough usually contain:

  • A centrally acting anti-tussive (either codeine or dextromethorphan; not both), with
  • Antihistamines, decongestants and expectorants.

Option A - Both of these drugs carry a risk of addiction, but it is not the reason to not give the drug. The main reason is that the combination is irrational.

Options B & D - Both codeine and dextromethorphan have different mechanisms of action and can treat cough effectively. However, the combination of two centrally acting antitussives does not provide any added advantage compared to using one drug alone. Hence, the combination is irrational.

questions.text: All of the following nerves are involved in the movement of the eyeball except:
questions.solution:
The nerve marked as 'A' is the optic nerve (II CN), and is not involved in the movement of the eyeball.

The nerves marked in the image are:

  1. Optic nerve (II CN)
  2. Oculomotor nerve (III CN)

Extraocular muscles involved in the movement of the eyeball:

  • Lateral rectus - supplied by abducens (VI) nerve.
